  - Arrange your initial Treasure cards face up in front of you, ensuring all players can see each other's resources.

- **Understand Objectives**:
  - Discuss the team's strategy to collect all four treasures and plan the escape from the island via Fools' Landing.
QuickSetupGuide.Gameplay:
**Player Turn Sequence**:
   - On your turn, perform the following in order:
     **Take up to 3 actions**:
        - **Move**: Navigate to adjacent tiles (orthogonally).
        - **Shore Up**: Flip a flooded tile (adjacent or occupied) to its un-flooded side.
        - **Give a Treasure Card**: Hand a Treasure card to a player on the same tile.
        - **Capture a Treasure**: If on a corresponding tile with 4 matching Treasure cards, discard them to claim the treasure.
     **Draw 2 Treasure Cards**:
        - Add these to your hand, adhering to the 5-card hand limit.
        - If a "Waters Rise!" card is drawn, immediately execute its instructions.
     **Draw Flood Cards**:
        - Draw a number of cards equal to the current Water Level.
        - For each, flip the corresponding tile to its flooded side or remove it if it's already flooded.

**Special Actions**:
   - **Waters Rise!**:
     - Increase the Water Level marker by one tick.
     - Shuffle the Flood discard pile and place it on top of the Flood draw pile.
   - **Helicopter Lift** and **Sandbags** cards:
     - Play these at any time to respectively move pawns or shore up any tile; these do not count as actions.

**Hand Limit**:
   - If exceeding 5 cards, immediately discard down to the limit, optionally playing Special Action cards before discarding.

**End of Turn**:
   - After drawing Flood cards, play passes to the next player.
QuickSetupGuide.EndOfGame: The game ends when all the treasures are collected and players escape, or if the island sinks.

QuickSetupGuide.Overview: A legacy-style dungeon crawl, where players explore dungeons, battle monsters, and make choices that affect the game's story.
QuickSetupGuide.Setup:
**Scenario Selection**: Choose a scenario to play from the Scenario Book, noting any prerequisites or required achievements.

**Map Setup**: Arrange the map tiles as indicated in the chosen scenario, placing overlay tiles, doors, and traps as specified.

**Monster Preparation**: For each monster type in the scenario, prepare the corresponding monster statistic card, ability deck, and standees. Place the monsters on the map as directed, ensuring their standee numbers are randomized.

**Player Area Setup**: Each player selects a character, taking the corresponding character mat, miniature, ability cards, and tracking dials. Players set their health and experience dials to the starting values indicated on their character mat.

**Attack Modifier Decks**: Each player prepares their personal attack modifier deck, consisting of 20 standard cards. The monster attack modifier deck is also prepared separately.

**Item Selection**: Players choose items from their available inventory to equip for the scenario, adhering to slot and quantity limitations.

**Battle Goals**: Deal two random battle goal cards to each player. Each player selects one to keep secret and discards the other.

**Initiative Order**: Determine the initiative order for the first round based on players' selected ability cards and revealed monster ability cards.
QuickSetupGuide.PlayerSetup:
- **Character Selection**: Each player chooses a character class, taking the corresponding character mat, miniature, and ability cards.

- **Ability Cards**: Players select a hand of ability cards for the scenario, adhering to the hand limit specified on their character mat.

- **Items**: Players equip items from their inventory, observing slot restrictions (e.g., one head item, one body item, etc.).

- **Battle Goals**: Each player draws two battle goal cards, selecting one to keep secret and discarding the other.

- **Health and Experience**: Set the health and experience dials to the starting values indicated on the character mat.
QuickSetupGuide.Gameplay:
**Round Structure**:
   - **Card Selection**: Players simultaneously select two ability cards to play, choosing one for its initiative value.
   - **Initiative Determination**: Reveal selected cards and monster ability cards to establish the initiative order.
   - **Character and Monster Turns**: In initiative order, each character and monster type takes a turn, performing actions as specified on their cards.
   - **End of Round**: Resolve any end-of-round effects, shuffle decks as needed, and advance any round trackers.

**Character Actions**:
   - **Ability Execution**: On a character's turn, perform the top action of one selected card and the bottom action of the other.
   - **Movement and Attacks**: Move across the map and engage in attacks, drawing from the attack modifier deck to determine outcomes.
   - **Resting**: To recover discarded cards, characters can take a short rest (randomly losing one card) or declare a long rest (recovering all discarded cards but losing one, and forfeiting the turn).

**Monster Behavior**:
   - **Ability Cards**: Each monster type reveals an ability card dictating their actions for the round.
   - **Focus and Targeting**: Monsters determine focus based on proximity and line of sight, moving and attacking according to their AI rules.
   - **Special Abilities**: Monsters may have unique traits or abilities as indicated on their statistic cards and ability cards.

**Conditions and Effects**:
   - **Status Conditions**: Apply conditions like Poison, Wound, Stun, etc., as dictated by abilities, affecting characters' and monsters' performance.
   - **Elemental Infusions**: Certain abilities generate or consume elemental energies, influencing the effectiveness of subsequent actions.

**Loot and Experience**:
   - **Collecting Loot**: Characters can pick up money tokens and treasure tiles by ending their movement on them or using specific loot actions.
   - **Gaining Experience**: Experience points are earned through specific actions and by completing scenarios, leading to character progression.
QuickSetupGuide.EndOfGame: The game ends after a set number of scenarios or when the players reach the final scenario. The player with the most points wins.

QuickSetupGuide.Overview: Jaws of the Lion: A more accessible version of Gloomhaven, with simplified rules and a smaller campaign, still offering deep tactical combat.
QuickSetupGuide.Setup:
**Scenario Selection**: Choose the starting scenario as indicated in the Scenario Book.

**Map Setup**: Open the Scenario Book to the chosen scenario and lay it flat to display the map. Place the required map tiles, tokens, and overlays as depicted.

**Monster Setup**: Identify the monsters for the scenario. Retrieve their stat cards, standees, and shuffle their ability decks.

**City Map Board**: Place the city map board nearby to track scenario progression and unlocked locations.

**Token and Deck Placement**: Arrange status tokens, money tokens, damage tokens, and shuffled attack modifier decks within reach of all players.
QuickSetupGuide.PlayerSetup:
1. **Character Selection**: Each player selects a character and takes the corresponding character mat, figure, and starting hand of ability cards.

2. **Hit Point Tracking**: Set the hit point dial to the character's starting health as indicated on their character mat.

3. **Attack Modifier Deck**: Each player takes their character's attack modifier deck, shuffles it, and places it face down.

4. **Ability Cards**: Players review their starting ability cards, selecting the appropriate number based on their character's hand limit.

5. **Initiative Order Token**: Place the character's initiative order token near the scenario map for tracking turn order.
QuickSetupGuide.Gameplay:
**Round Structure**:
   - **Card Selection**: Players simultaneously select two ability cards to play, determining their actions and initiative for the round.
   - **Initiative Determination**: Reveal selected cards and arrange initiative order from lowest to highest.
   - **Character Turns**: In initiative order, players perform the top action of one card and the bottom action of the other.
   - **Monster Turns**: After characters, monsters act based on their revealed ability cards.
   - **End of Round**: Resolve any end-of-round effects and prepare for the next round.

**Actions**:
   - **Movement**: Navigate the map by moving a number of hexes up to the movement value.
   - **Attacks**: Engage enemies using melee or ranged attacks, drawing from the attack modifier deck to determine damage.
   - **Abilities**: Utilize special actions such as healing, looting, or applying status effects as described on ability cards.

**Resting**:
   - **Short Rest**: At the end of a round, recover discarded ability cards by randomly losing one.
   - **Long Rest**: Declare a long rest to recover cards, heal, and refresh spent items, but forfeit the character's turn for that round.

**Status Effects**: Apply conditions like poison, wound, stun, and others as indicated, affecting characters' and monsters' capabilities.

**Looting**: Collect money tokens and treasure tiles by ending movement on their hex or using specific loot actions.

**Scenario Objectives**: Fulfill the specific goal outlined in the Scenario Book to achieve success.
QuickSetupGuide.EndOfGame: Jaws of the Lion: The game ends after completing the final scenario. The player with the most points wins.

QuickSetupGuide.Overview: A single-player logic game where players navigate marbles through a maze of towers to reach the target.
QuickSetupGuide.Setup:
**Game Components**:
   - Game Grid: The base where towers are placed.
   - Towers: 9 translucent pieces of varying heights and configurations.
   - Marbles: 3 steel marbles (1 for gameplay, 2 spares).
   - Challenge Cards: 60 cards detailing setup and objectives.

**Initial Setup**:
   - Place the game grid on a flat surface.
   - Shuffle the challenge cards and select one to begin.
   - Position the towers on the grid as indicated in the "Setup" section of the chosen challenge card, ensuring correct placement and orientation.
QuickSetupGuide.PlayerSetup:
- **Select a Challenge**: Choose a challenge card that matches your desired difficulty level.
- **Review the Objective**: Understand the starting and target positions as outlined on the card.
- **Prepare the Components**: Gather the indicated towers and a marble to begin constructing the maze.
QuickSetupGuide.Gameplay:
**Analyze the Challenge Card**:
   - Observe the initial tower placements and the list of additional towers under "Add to Grid."

**Construct the Maze**:
   - Strategically place the additional towers on the grid to create a continuous path for the marble.
   - Adhere to building rules:
     - Towers must connect via flanges.
     - Maximum stack height is three towers.
     - Horizontal towers require support from at least two vertical towers.
     - The marble should descend one level at a time and cannot travel horizontally more than one unit without descending.

**Test the Maze**:
   - Once constructed, release the marble from the start position.
   - A successful configuration will guide the marble to the target tower.

**Adjust if Necessary**:
   - If the marble doesn't reach the target, reassess and modify the tower placements accordingly.
QuickSetupGuide.EndOfGame: The game ends after the player successfully completes the puzzle or gives up.

QuickSetupGuide.Overview: A cooperative card game where players try to create a beautiful firework display by playing cards in the correct order.
QuickSetupGuide.Setup:
**Prepare the Game Components**:
   - **Information Tokens**: Place 8 blue tokens (representing clues) in a central area accessible to all players.
   - **Fuse Tokens**: Arrange 3 red tokens (representing mistakes) nearby.
   - **Deck Setup**: Shuffle the 50-card deck, which consists of five colors (white, yellow, green, blue, and red), each containing cards numbered 1 through 5 in specific distributions: three 1s, two 2s, two 3s, two 4s, and one **Deal Cards to Players**:
   - For 2 or 3 players: Deal 5 cards to each player.
   - For 4 or 5 players: Deal 4 cards to each player.

   **Important**: Players must hold their cards facing outward, so they cannot see their own cards but can see the cards of their teammates.

**Game Area Setup**:
   - Designate space on the table for five potential piles (one for each color) where cards will be played in ascending order to build the fireworks.
   - Reserve an area for a discard pile where players will place discarded cards.
QuickSetupGuide.PlayerSetup:
- **Card Handling**: Without looking at the front of their own cards, players hold their hands so that only their fellow players can see them.

- **Initial Observations**: Players take note of their teammates' cards, as this information will be crucial for providing helpful clues during the game.
QuickSetupGuide.Gameplay:
On a player's turn, they must choose one of the following actions:

**Give Information**:
   - **Cost**: Flip one blue information token from the available pool to the used side.
   - **Action**: Point to all cards of a single color or number in another player's hand and announce them. For example:
     - "These two cards are red."
     - "This card is a "
   - **Note**: The hint must be complete and accurate, identifying all cards of the mentioned color or number in that player's hand.

**Discard a Card**:
   - **Action**: Choose a card from your own hand to discard face-up into the discard pile.
   - **Benefit**: Restore one used blue information token back to the available pool.
   - **Draw**: Draw a new card from the deck, placing it into your hand without looking at its front.

**Play a Card**:
   - **Action**: Select a card from your hand to play onto the table.
   - **Outcome**:
     - If the card continues or starts a firework (i.e., it is the next number in sequence for its color starting from 1), place it on the corresponding color pile.
     - If the card cannot be placed correctly:
       - Place it in the discard pile.
       - Flip one red fuse token as a penalty.
   - **Draw**: Draw a new card from the deck, adding it to your hand without viewing its front.

**Game End Conditions**:
- The game concludes immediately if all three red fuse tokens are flipped, resulting in a loss.
- If players successfully complete all five fireworks (each color pile reaching the number 5), they achieve a perfect game.
- When the draw deck is exhausted, players continue until each has taken one final turn. The game then ends, and the team's score is calculated based on the highest number card in each color pile, with a maximum possible score of
QuickSetupGuide.EndOfGame: The game ends when the players complete the firework display or fail to meet the required conditions.

QuickSetupGuide.Overview: Cooperative deck-building game where players work together as Hogwarts students to defeat villains and protect the wizarding world.
QuickSetupGuide.Setup:
1. Place the game board on the table.
2. Shuffle the Hogwarts cards and place them in their designated space.
3. Place the Villain deck and Dark Arts deck in their respective spaces.
4. Set the Location cards in order, starting with the first location on top.
5. Place the Horcrux and Encounter cards (if applicable) nearby.
6. Set the Influence tokens, Attack tokens, and Health trackers within reach.
QuickSetupGuide.PlayerSetup:
- Each player selects a Hero (Harry, Ron, Hermione, or Neville).
- Take the corresponding Hero Deck (10 starting cards).
- Shuffle and place the Hero Deck face down as the draw pile.
- Draw 5 cards as the starting hand.
- Place a Player Board in front of each player.
- Set starting Health to 10 on the Player Board.
- Place Influence tokens nearby.
QuickSetupGuide.Gameplay:
**1. Reveal the Dark Arts card and resolve its effect.**  
**2. Resolve any Villain abilities that trigger at the start of a turn.**  
**3. Play cards from hand to gain Influence, Attack, or Health.**  
**4. Use Influence to acquire new cards from the market.**  
**5. Assign Attack to Villains.**  
**6. Discard remaining cards and draw a new hand.**  
**7. Replenish the market and pass to the next player.**
QuickSetupGuide.EndOfGame:
The game ends when either:  
  - Players successfully defeat all villains in the final scenario.  
  - All locations are controlled by villains, resulting in player loss.

QuickSetupGuide.Overview: A lighthearted, fantasy-themed card game where players build a party of heroes and try to slay monsters.
QuickSetupGuide.Setup:
**Separate Decks**: Divide the cards into their respective types: Party Leader cards, Monster cards, and the main deck (comprising Hero, Item, Magic, Modifier, and Challenge cards).

**Choose Party Leaders**: Each player selects a Party Leader card to represent them. To determine the selection order, players can roll dice or choose another random method. Once chosen, place any unselected Party Leader cards back in the box.

**Distribute Reference Cards**: Provide each player with a rules reference card for guidance during gameplay.

**Prepare the Main Deck**: Shuffle the main deck thoroughly and deal five cards to each player. Place the remaining cards face down in the center of the table to form the draw pile, leaving space beside it for a discard pile.

**Set Up Monster Cards**: Shuffle the Monster cards and reveal the top three, placing them face up in the center of the table. The remaining Monster cards form a face-down Monster deck.

**Establish Player Areas**: Each player places their chosen Party Leader card face up in front of them, designating their Party area where Heroes and Items will be played.
QuickSetupGuide.PlayerSetup:
- **Party Leader Placement**: Place your selected Party Leader card face up in your designated Party area.

- **Initial Hand**: Ensure you have five cards drawn from the main deck.

- **Action Points**: Familiarize yourself with the concept of action points; each player has three action points to spend on their turn for various actions.
QuickSetupGuide.Gameplay:
**Turn Sequence**: Players take turns in a clockwise order. On your turn, you have three action points to spend on the following actions:

   - **Draw a Card**: Spend 1 action point to draw the top card from the main deck into your hand.

   - **Play a Hero, Item, or Magic Card**: Spend 1 action point to play one of these cards from your hand into your Party or apply its effect. When playing a Hero card, you may immediately roll two dice to attempt activating its effect.

   - **Activate a Hero's Effect**: Spend 1 action point to roll two dice and try to use an effect of a Hero card already in your Party. Note that each Hero's effect can only be attempted once per turn.

   - **Attack a Monster**: Spend 2 action points to attack a face-up Monster card in the center of the table, provided you meet its Party requirements.

   - **Refresh Your Hand**: Spend 3 action points to discard your entire hand and draw five new cards from the main deck.

**Challenges**: If another player plays a Hero, Item, or Magic card, you may play a Challenge card to attempt to negate their action. Both players roll two dice; if the challenger?s roll is equal to or higher than the other player's roll, the challenged card is discarded without effect.

**Modifiers**: You can play Modifier cards from your hand to adjust any player's dice roll (including your own), either increasing or decreasing the result as specified on the Modifier card.

**Ending Your Turn**: After spending your action points, or if you choose to take no further actions, your turn ends, and play passes to the next player clockwise.

**Winning the Game**: The game ends when a player either slays three Monster cards or assembles a full Party containing six different classes, including their Party Leader. That player is declared the winner.
QuickSetupGuide.EndOfGame: The game ends when a player slays three monsters or their party reaches full strength.

QuickSetupGuide.Overview: A deck-building game where players create powerful combos and battle opponents with various heroes.
QuickSetupGuide.Setup:
**Health Tracking**: Each player sets their starting health to **Starting Deck**: Each player shuffles a personal deck containing:
   - 7 Gold cards
   - 1 Shortsword card
   - 1 Dagger card
   - 1 Ruby card

**Market Setup**: Shuffle the Market Deck and reveal the top five cards, placing them face-up in the center as the Market Row. Place the Fire Gem cards in a pile accessible to all players.

**Determine First Player**: Randomly select a starting player. The first player draws a three-card hand; the second player draws four cards; all other players draw five cards.
QuickSetupGuide.PlayerSetup:
- **Deck and Hand**: Each player shuffles their personal deck and draws their initial hand based on turn order.

- **Play Area**: Designate space for a personal discard pile and in-play area for champions and actions.

- **Health Tracker**: Use a method (such as a scorecard or app) to monitor your health, starting at 50.
QuickSetupGuide.Gameplay:
**Starting Phase**: Begin your turn.

**Main Phase**:
   - **Play Cards**: Play cards from your hand to generate Gold, Combat, and other effects.
   - **Acquire Cards**: Use Gold to purchase cards from the Market Row or Fire Gems, placing acquired cards into your discard pile.
   - **Combat**: Use Combat to attack opponents or their champions. Opponents' guards must be defeated before targeting them directly or their non-guard champions.

**Discard Phase**: Place all played and unplayed cards into your discard pile.

**Draw Phase**: Draw five new cards. If your deck is empty, shuffle your discard pile to form a new deck and continue drawing.

**End Phase**: Conclude your turn; the next player begins theirs.
QuickSetupGuide.EndOfGame: The game ends when one player?s health reaches zero, and the other player wins.

QuickSetupGuide.Overview: A fast-paced two-player card game where players are merchants competing to earn the most profit by buying and selling goods.
QuickSetupGuide.Setup:
**Market Setup**: Place 3 camel cards face up between the players to form the starting market.
**Deck Preparation**: Shuffle the remaining cards and deal 5 to each player. These are the players' starting hands.
**Market Completion**: Draw 2 additional cards from the deck and place them face up next to the camel cards, completing the 5-card market.
**Player Herds**: Players reveal any camel cards from their hands and place them face up in front of them; this forms their herd.
**Token Arrangement**: Sort the goods tokens by type and arrange each stack in descending order of value. Shuffle the bonus tokens separately by type and place them in three face-down piles. Position the camel token and the three Seals of Excellence within reach.
**Starting Player**: Determine the first player by mutual agreement or random choice.
QuickSetupGuide.PlayerSetup:
- **Hand Composition**: Each player starts with a hand of 5 cards, excluding any camels, which are placed in their herd.
- **Herd**: Camels collected from the initial hand are placed face up in front of the player and do not count towards the hand limit.
- **Hand Limit**: Players may have a maximum of 7 goods cards in hand; camels in the herd are exempt from this limit.
QuickSetupGuide.Gameplay:
On a player's turn, they must choose one of two actions:

**Take Cards**:
   - **Take One Good**: Select a single goods card from the market and add it to your hand. Replace the taken card with the top card from the deck.
   - **Exchange Multiple Goods**: Take two or more goods cards from the market and replace them with an equal number of cards from your hand and/or camels from your herd.
   - **Take All Camels**: Collect all camel cards from the market and add them to your herd. Refill the market by drawing cards from the deck equal to the number of camels taken.

**Sell Cards**:
   - **Choose Goods to Sell**: Select one type of goods card from your hand and discard any number of those cards to the discard pile.
   - **Collect Tokens**: For each card sold, take the corresponding goods token from the stack, starting with the highest value.
   - **Receive Bonus Tokens**: If selling 3, 4, or 5+ cards in a single turn, draw the respective bonus token, which remains face down until scoring.

**Hand Limit Reminder**: Players may not exceed 7 goods cards in hand at any time; camels do not count towards this limit.
QuickSetupGuide.EndOfGame: The game ends after two rounds, and the player with the most points wins.

QuickSetupGuide.Overview: A tile-laying game where players gather fruit and manage an island to earn points.
QuickSetupGuide.Setup:
**Island Boards**: Each player receives an island board, placing it in front of them.

**Fruit Tokens**: Place the fruit tokens (bananas, limes, oranges, pomegranates, and mangosteens) in a general supply accessible to all players.

**Ship Tokens**: Randomly draw and place ship tokens on the designated dock spaces around each player's island.

**Business Board**: Set up the central business board with available business tiles and the license track.

**Juice Factory (Optional Advanced Variant)**: If playing with the juice factory, place the juice factory board nearby, along with the corresponding components.
QuickSetupGuide.PlayerSetup:
- **Fruit Collectors**: Each player starts with five fruit collector tokens placed on their island's grid.

- **Score Markers**: Place each player's score marker on the starting position of the score track.

- **Personal Supply**: Players begin with no fruit in their personal supply.
QuickSetupGuide.Gameplay:
**Harvesting Fruit**: On your turn, slide a fruit collector token in a straight line on your island's grid. The number of spaces moved determines the amount of that fruit type you collect. Collectors cannot move through other tokens.

**Fulfilling Ship Orders**: Spend the required fruit to fulfill an order for a ship adjacent to your island. Remove the ship token, freeing up space for future movements, and gain the points indicated.

**Acquiring Businesses**: Spend fruit to acquire business tiles from the business board. Place these tiles on your island, which may provide immediate or ongoing benefits and points.

**Juice Factory (If Using)**: Instead of the above actions, you may choose to produce juice by moving your discs in the juice factory, converting fruit into points.

**End of Turn**: Replenish any emptied business spaces on the business board. Play proceeds clockwise.
QuickSetupGuide.EndOfGame: The game ends when the last fruit is taken from the center, and the player with the most points wins.

QuickSetupGuide.Overview: Cooperative party game where players give one-word clues to help a teammate guess a secret word.
QuickSetupGuide.Setup:
1. Give each player a marker and an easel.
2. Shuffle the deck of word cards and place it face down.
3. Determine the starting player.
QuickSetupGuide.PlayerSetup:
- Shuffle the deck of Word cards and place it in the center.
- Each player takes a small dry-erase board and marker.
- Select a starting active player.
QuickSetupGuide.Gameplay:
**1. The active player selects a number without seeing the word associated with it.**  
**2. Other players write down one-word clues related to the secret word.**  
**3. Duplicate clues are eliminated.**  
**4. The active player sees the remaining clues and makes a guess.**  
**5. The round ends, and the next player takes a turn as the guesser.**
QuickSetupGuide.EndOfGame: The game ends when all players have given clues and the final word is guessed.

QuickSetupGuide.Overview: Dice-rolling game where players take on the roles of monsters battling to become the king of Tokyo through attacks and special powers.
QuickSetupGuide.Setup:
1. Place the Tokyo board in the center.
2. Shuffle the deck of Power cards and place it face down.
3. Place the Energy cubes, dice, and tokens within reach.
4. Each player chooses a Monster and takes the corresponding figure and board.
QuickSetupGuide.PlayerSetup:
- Each player selects a Monster and takes the corresponding Monster board.
- Set Health to 10 and Victory Points to 0 on the Monster board.
- Shuffle the deck of Power cards and place it in the center.
- Reveal the top 3 Power cards as the market.
- Place the Energy cubes within reach of all players.
- Roll dice to determine the first player (most Attack results starts).
QuickSetupGuide.Gameplay:
**1. Roll six dice (up to three times, keeping or rerolling any number of dice).**  
**2. Resolve dice results: Attack (damage opponents), Energy (gain energy cubes), Heal (restore health), Points (gain stars).**  
**3. If dealing damage, the current Tokyo occupant takes it and may choose to yield.**  
**4. If entering Tokyo, gain 1 star.**  
**5. Spend energy cubes to purchase power cards.**  
**6. Check if any player reaches 20 stars or is the last monster standing.**
QuickSetupGuide.EndOfGame: The game ends when a player reaches **20 Victory Points** or is the **last monster standing**.

QuickSetupGuide.Overview: A tile-laying game where players build their kingdoms by matching tiles with different terrain types to earn points.
QuickSetupGuide.Setup:
Prepare the Tiles:

Shuffle all domino tiles and place them in a face-down draw pile.

Depending on the player count, remove specific tiles:

2 Players: Use all tiles.

3 Players: Remove 12 tiles.

4 Players: Use all tiles.
QuickSetupGuide.PlayerSetup:
Each player takes a starting square tile and a castle.

Each player takes a colored king pawn (two per player in a 2-player game, one otherwise).

Randomly determine player order.
QuickSetupGuide.Gameplay:
Tile Selection:
Players select tiles in the order of their king pawn placement.

New tiles are drawn and arranged for the next round.

Placing Tiles:

The selected tile must be placed in a 5x5 grid adjacent to an existing tile.

At least one side of the new tile must match a terrain type of an adjacent tile.
QuickSetupGuide.EndOfGame: The game ends after each player has completed a 5x5 grid. The player with the most points wins.

QuickSetupGuide.Overview: A classic family game where players navigate through a shifting maze to collect treasure and reach their goals.
QuickSetupGuide.Setup:
**Game Board Setup**:
   - Place the game board in the center of the playing area.
   - The board features 16 fixed path tiles forming a grid with empty spaces.

**Path Tiles**:
   - Shuffle the 34 square path tiles face down.
   - Randomly place 33 of them face up on the empty spaces of the game board, creating a continuous maze.
   - Keep the remaining tile aside; it will be used during gameplay.

**Treasure Cards**:
   - Shuffle the 24 treasure cards thoroughly.
   - Deal them evenly among all players, face down. Each player should have their own stack.
   - Players may look at the top card of their stack but must keep it hidden from others.

**Playing Pieces**:
   - Each player selects a colored playing piece and places it on the corresponding colored corner of the board.

**Determine Starting Player**:
   - Choose a player to begin; turns will proceed clockwise.
QuickSetupGuide.PlayerSetup:
- **Treasure Cards**: Without revealing them to others, look at the top card of your stack to identify your current target treasure.

- **Starting Position**: Place your playing piece on the corner square that matches your piece's color.

- **Objective**: Plan your moves to navigate the maze, collect your treasures in order, and return to your starting position.
QuickSetupGuide.Gameplay:
**Shifting the Maze**:
   - On your turn, take the extra path tile and insert it into the maze at any of the 12 entry points marked by arrows along the board's edge.
   - Push the tile into the chosen row or column, shifting all tiles in that line and pushing the last tile off the board.
   - The tile that is pushed off becomes the new extra tile for the next player.
   - Note: You cannot reverse the previous player's move by immediately undoing their tile placement.

**Moving Your Playing Piece**:
   - After shifting the maze, you may move your piece as far as desired along open pathways.
   - Movement can continue through any number of connected path tiles but cannot pass through walls.
   - If you reach the space depicting your current treasure, reveal your treasure card to confirm, then look at your next card to identify your new target.
   - If you cannot reach your target, position your piece strategically for your next turn.

**Special Situations**:
   - If a player's piece is on a tile that is pushed off the board, place their piece on the newly inserted tile on the opposite side. This does not count as a move for that player.
QuickSetupGuide.EndOfGame: The game ends when a player reaches the treasure or the game?s objective.

QuickSetupGuide.Overview: A space-themed strategy game where players race to develop their civilizations and claim victory points.
QuickSetupGuide.Setup:
**Board Setup**:
   - Assemble the modular game board, ensuring the central star is in place.
   - Randomly distribute 3D planet models across designated sectors.
   - Place exploration tokens face down on unexplored planets.

**Resource and Component Preparation**:
   - Sort resource tokens (e.g., minerals, energy) into separate pools within reach of all players.
   - Arrange ship models, extractors, and other components nearby.

**Faction Selection**:
   - Each player selects or is assigned a unique alien faction board, detailing special abilities and starting resources.

**Starting Positions**:
   - Players place their starting ships and extractors on their designated home planets as indicated on their faction boards.

**Action Cards**:
   - Shuffle the universal action card deck and deal a set number to each player, forming their starting hand.

**Turn Order**:
   - Determine the first player through a chosen method (e.g., highest die roll).
QuickSetupGuide.PlayerSetup:
- **Faction Abilities**: Review your faction board to understand unique powers and starting conditions.

- **Initial Resources**: Collect starting resources as specified on your faction board.

- **Action Cards**: Familiarize yourself with your initial hand of action cards, which dictate possible actions each turn.

- **Ship and Extractor Placement**: Position your starting ships and extractors on your home planet or designated starting area.
QuickSetupGuide.Gameplay:
**Simultaneous Action Selection**:
   - Players choose an action card from their hand and place it face down.

**Action Resolution**:
   - Reveal action cards simultaneously.
   - Resolve actions in a predetermined order, typically:
     - **Research**: Acquire new technologies or abilities.
     - **Mine**: Gather resources from controlled planets.
     - **Construct**: Build ships or extractors to expand influence.
     - **Trade**: Exchange resources with other players or the bank.
     - **Refresh**: Recover used action cards and reset certain abilities.
     - **Command**: Move ships and engage in combat.

**Board Rotation**:
   - After resolving actions, rotate the game board (or specific rings) as per game rules, altering strategic positions and access.

**Resource Management and Upkeep**:
   - Manage collected resources to fund actions, constructions, and technological advancements.

**Victory Check**:
   - At the end of each round, check if any player has achieved the required amount of light to win the game.
QuickSetupGuide.EndOfGame: The game ends when a player reaches the final round, and the player with the most points wins.

Game: Legendary: A Marvel Deck Building Game

QuickSetupGuide.Overview: A Marvel Deck Building Game: A cooperative deck-building game where players recruit Marvel heroes to fight villains and save the world.
QuickSetupGuide.Setup:
**Select Mastermind and Scheme**: Choose a Mastermind villain and a Scheme they are attempting to execute. Place the Mastermind card and its associated Master Strikes in their designated area.

**Assemble Villain Deck**: Based on the chosen Scheme, gather the required Villain groups, Henchmen groups, Scheme Twists, and Bystanders. Shuffle these cards together to form the Villain Deck.

**Prepare Hero Deck**: Select heroes as dictated by the number of players (typically five heroes for a standard game). Shuffle all chosen Hero cards to create the Hero Deck.

**Set Up the Board**: Place the S.H.I.E.L.D. Officer Stack, Wound Stack, and Bystander Stack in their respective spaces on the board. Draw five Hero cards from the Hero Deck and place them face-up in the HQ spaces.

**Player Starting Decks**: Each player receives a starting deck of 8 S.H.I.E.L.D. Agent cards and 4 S.H.I.E.L.D. Trooper cards. Shuffle your deck and draw six cards to form your starting hand.

**Determine Starting Player**: Choose a player to go first. Turns will proceed clockwise from the starting player.
QuickSetupGuide.PlayerSetup:
- **Deck and Hand**: Each player begins with a personal deck of 12 cards (8 S.H.I.E.L.D. Agents and 4 S.H.I.E.L.D. Troopers). After shuffling, draw an initial hand of six cards.

- **Play Area**: Designate space in front of you for your play area, where you'll play cards, recruit heroes, and fight villains.

- **Player Mat (Optional)**: If available, use a player mat to organize your play area, deck, and discard pile.
QuickSetupGuide.Gameplay:
**Villain Phase**:
   - Draw the top card of the Villain Deck and resolve its effects. This may involve villains entering the city, Scheme Twists altering the game state, or Master Strikes triggering the Mastermind's abilities.

**Hero Phase**:
   - **Play Cards**: Play cards from your hand to generate Recruit Points (for recruiting heroes) and Attack Points (for battling villains).
   - **Recruit Heroes**: Spend Recruit Points to acquire hero cards from the HQ, placing them into your discard pile.
   - **Fight Villains**: Use Attack Points to defeat villains in the city or confront the Mastermind. Defeated villains are placed in your victory pile.

**Draw Phase**:
   - Discard any remaining cards in your hand and draw a new hand of six cards. If your deck is empty, shuffle your discard pile to form a new deck.

**End of Turn**:
   - Play passes to the next player clockwise.

**Additional Rules**:
   - **Escaping Villains**: If a villain moves off the city track, it escapes, potentially causing negative effects.
   - **Wounds**: Certain effects may cause players to gain Wound cards, which clutter your deck and reduce efficiency.
   - **Bystanders**: Rescuing Bystanders can provide bonuses and are added to your victory pile.
QuickSetupGuide.EndOfGame: A Marvel Deck Building Game: The game ends when the final villain is defeated, or the heroes are overpowered. The player with the most points wins.

QuickSetupGuide.Overview: Cooperative word game where players give and interpret clues to deduce their hidden letters and form a word.
QuickSetupGuide.Setup:
1. Arrange the letter cards into a deck and shuffle.
2. Place the clue tokens, number tokens, and green tokens within reach.
3. Set up the clue sheet and pencils for each player.
QuickSetupGuide.PlayerSetup:
- Each player selects a set of Letter cards, shuffles, and forms a word.
- Place Letter cards face down in a stack in front of the player.
- Reveal the top Letter card on a stand, facing outward.
- Place the numbered clue tokens within reach.
- Set up the Clue Tracker board.
- Place the Wildcard Letter in the center.
QuickSetupGuide.Gameplay:
**1. Each player has a letter card in front of them, visible to all but themselves.**  
**2. Players take turns forming words using the visible letters.**  
**3. The clue giver provides the word by placing number tokens for letter order.**  
**4. Players deduce their letter based on clues and write guesses.**  
**5. When ready, swap letters and continue until all letters are used.**
QuickSetupGuide.EndOfGame: The game ends when all players either successfully guess their word or run out of clue cards.

QuickSetupGuide.Overview: A two-player card game where players embark on expeditions to score points by playing cards in sequence.
QuickSetupGuide.Setup:
**Game Board Setup**:
   - Place the game board between both players. It features five colored spaces corresponding to the five expeditions and areas for discard piles.

**Card Preparation**:
   - Shuffle the 60-card deck, comprising:
     - 45 Expedition cards (values 2?10 in five colors).
     - 15 Wager cards (three per color).
   - Deal eight cards face down to each player.
   - Place the remaining deck face down as the draw pile beside the board.

**Discard Piles**:
   - Ensure space is available for five separate discard piles, one for each color.
QuickSetupGuide.PlayerSetup:
- **Hand Management**: Each player starts with eight cards in hand.

- **Player Area**: On your side of the board, you'll build columns for each expedition you undertake, placing cards in ascending order.

- **Discard Access**: Both players share access to the five discard piles, which can influence drawing strategies.
QuickSetupGuide.Gameplay:
**Playing a Card**:
   - On your turn, choose one card from your hand to either:
     - **Start/Extend an Expedition**: Place a card on your side to begin or continue a colored expedition. Cards must be in ascending order; wager cards precede numbered cards.
     - **Discard a Card**: Place a card on the corresponding color's discard pile if it's not immediately useful.

**Drawing a Card**:
   - After playing, draw a card to replenish your hand to eight cards. You may draw from:
     - The top of the draw pile.
     - The top card of any discard pile (except the one you just discarded to).

**Game End Condition**:
   - Turns alternate until the draw pile is exhausted, signaling the end of the round.

**Scoring**:
   - For each expedition:
     - Sum the values of cards played.
     - Subtract 20 points as the expedition's cost.
     - Multiply the result by the number of wager cards plus one.
     - Add a 20-point bonus if the expedition has eight or more cards.
   - Calculate the total for all expeditions to determine the round's score.

**Subsequent Rounds**:
   - Shuffle all cards and repeat setup for the next round. The game consists of three rounds in total.
QuickSetupGuide.EndOfGame: The game ends when all cards have been drawn, and the player with the most points wins.

QuickSetupGuide.Overview: A worker placement and deck-building game where players explore an ancient jungle, discovering artifacts and uncovering secrets.
QuickSetupGuide.Setup:
Prepare the Game Board:

Place the main board in the center of the play area, ensuring the correct side is facing up based on player count.
Shuffle the Artifact and Item cards separately, placing them face-down on their designated spaces. Reveal the top five Item cards to form the item market.
Place the Idol tokens on the unexplored site spaces (Level 1 and Level 2 sites) as indicated.
Shuffle the Site and Guardian tiles separately, placing them face-down near the board.
Arrange the Research Track components:
Place the Research tokens (magnifying glass and notebook) of each player at the bottom of the track.
Shuffle and place the Research bonus tiles face-up on their designated spaces.
Stack the Temple tiles at the top of the track.
QuickSetupGuide.PlayerSetup:
1. **Game Board**: Place the main board in the center, using the Bird Temple side for the initial game.

2. **Supply Setup**: Sort and place resources (coins, compasses, tablets, arrowheads, jewels) and tokens (idols, temple tiles, research bonus tiles) in their designated areas.

3. **Card Preparation**: Shuffle the artifact and item decks separately, placing them on their spots. Reveal the top five item cards and place them in the item row.

4. **Site and Guardian Tiles**: Shuffle level 1 and level 2 site tiles into separate stacks, placing them face down. Do the same with guardian tiles.

5. **Assistant Tiles**: Shuffle the assistant tiles and place one face up on each space of the supply board.

6. **Player Setup**: Each player selects a color and receives the corresponding player board, two archaeologist figures, research tokens (book and magnifying glass), and a starting deck of six cards (two Fear cards and four basic cards).

7. **Starting Resources**: Determine the starting player. In clockwise order from the starting player, distribute starting resources:

   - 1st player: 2 coins

   - 2nd player: 1 coin and 1 compass

   - 3rd player: 2 compasses

   - 4th player: 1 coin and 2 compasses

8. **Moon Staff**: Place the moon staff on the leftmost space above the item row to indicate the first round.

9. **Final Checks**: Ensure all components are in their designated places, and each player shuffles their starting deck, placing it face down on their player board.
QuickSetupGuide.Gameplay:
The game is played over five rounds, with players taking turns to perform one main action per turn until all pass. Main actions include:

**Dig at a Site**: Send an archaeologist to a discovered site to gain its resources.

**Discover a New Site**: Spend compasses to explore an undiscovered site, placing an archaeologist there, gaining an idol, and revealing a new site with its guardian.

**Overcome a Guardian**: Defeat a guardian at your archaeologist's location by paying its required resources, earning rewards and avoiding fear penalties.

**Buy a Card**: Purchase an item or artifact card by paying its cost, adding it to your deck for future use.

**Play a Card**: Use a card from your hand for its effect, then place it in your play area.

**Research**: Advance your magnifying glass or book token on the research track by paying the required resources, gaining bonuses and victory points.

Free actions, indicated by a lightning bolt symbol, can be performed any time during your turn without consuming your main action.
QuickSetupGuide.EndOfGame: The game ends after all of the expedition tokens have been placed or when the last artifact card is drawn. The player with the most points wins.

QuickSetupGuide.Overview: A dungeon crawler where players take on the role of heroes exploring dark environments to defeat enemies and gain loot.
QuickSetupGuide.Setup:
**Select Quest**: Choose a quest from the quest book and set up the game tiles as indicated.

**Prepare Hero Dashboards**: Each player selects a hero and takes the corresponding dashboard, miniature, and class components. Attach the colored base to the hero miniature and place the level token in the level slot on the dashboard, starting at level **Distribute Starting Equipment**: Lay out the starting equipment cards. Each hero selects one starting weapon, one starting armor, and one potion (health or mana) and places them in the appropriate slots on their dashboard.

**Set Up Lifebringer Tokens**: Place two Lifebringer tokens face-up within reach of all players.

**Arrange Game Components**: Shuffle the Door, Mob, Roaming Monster, and Treasure decks separately. Place the Darkness track and marker nearby. Position all monster miniatures, tokens, and dice within easy reach.

**Spawn Initial Mobs**: For each white spawn point on the game tiles, draw a card from the Level 1?2 Mob deck and place the corresponding miniatures (one leader and a number of minions equal to the number of heroes) on the spawn point. Equip each mob with a Level 1?2 monster item by drawing from the appropriate deck.

**Position Heroes**: Place all hero miniatures in the designated starting zone as specified by the quest.

**Prepare Treasure Bag**: Place the specified number of Common, Rare, and Epic Treasure tokens into the Treasure bag as directed by the quest setup.
QuickSetupGuide.PlayerSetup:
- **Hero Dashboard Setup**: Each player places their hero card into the hero slot on their dashboard. Insert pegs into the experience track at "0" and the level track at "1".

- **Equip Starting Items**: Players equip their chosen weapon and armor in the appropriate slots on their dashboard. Potions are placed next to the dashboard.

- **Class Components**: Depending on the chosen class, players set up any additional components or tokens as described in their class rules.
QuickSetupGuide.Gameplay:
The game progresses through a series of rounds, each consisting of four phases:

**Hero Phase**: Players decide the activation order for their heroes. Each hero performs three actions, choosing from:
   - **Move**: Spend movement points to navigate the dungeon or interact with objects.
   - **Combat**: Engage enemies in melee, ranged, or magic attacks.
   - **Trade and Equip**: Exchange items with other heroes in the same zone and adjust equipped items.
   - **Special Actions**: Use class-specific abilities or interact with quest-specific elements.

**Enemy Phase**: All enemies activate, performing actions based on their AI:
   - **Mobs**: Groups of enemies that attack heroes within range or move toward the nearest hero if no targets are in range.
   - **Roaming Monsters**: Powerful singular enemies with unique behaviors and attack patterns.

**Level Up Phase**: Heroes can spend accumulated experience points to gain new skills or enhance existing ones, increasing their effectiveness in combat and exploration.

**Darkness Phase**: The Darkness track advances, potentially spawning new enemies or triggering events that escalate the dungeon's danger.
QuickSetupGuide.EndOfGame: The game ends when players defeat the final boss or are all eliminated.

QuickSetupGuide.Overview: A push-your-luck game where players explore dungeons, earn treasure, and decide when to push their luck for more rewards.
QuickSetupGuide.Setup:
**Arrange Building Cards**:
   - Place all six types of star building cards in a row at the center of the play area, each type in its own pile, face up.
   - Choose seven types of normal building cards and place them below the star buildings in separate face-up piles. For the first game, ensure a variety of costs (1-5) are included.

**Prepare Level and Treasure Decks**:
   - Shuffle the level cards and place them face down next to the level tile.
   - Shuffle the treasure cards and place them face down within reach.

**Set Up Supply**:
   - Place heart tokens, jump tokens, and coin tokens in a designated supply area.
   - Position the heart cost card nearby to reference during gameplay.

**Distribute Player Materials**:
   - Each player selects a character token and receives a corresponding player card.
   - Provide each player with four heart tokens, placing them on the "heart" side of their player card.

**Determine First Player**:
   - The player who most recently played a video game receives the first-player token and will start the game.
QuickSetupGuide.PlayerSetup:
- **Character Placement**: Each player places their character token on the level tile, indicating participation in the upcoming run.

- **Initial Treasure Draw**: All players draw one treasure card from the treasure deck and place it above their player card; this represents the treasure carried during the run.

- **Heart Tokens**: Ensure all four heart tokens are on the "heart" side of the player card, representing the player's health during runs.
QuickSetupGuide.Gameplay:
**Run the Level**:
   - All players simultaneously place their character tokens on the level tile and draw one treasure card, placing it above their player card.
   - The first player reveals the top card of the level deck:
     - For each skull symbol on the card, all players on the level tile move one heart token to the "injury" side of their player card.
     - If a player uses a jump token before revealing a level card with a jump symbol, they avoid all damage from that card.
   - After resolving the level card, players decide to:
     - **Stay**: Draw an additional treasure card and continue to the next level card.
     - **Return Home**: Remove their character from the level tile, securing collected treasures by moving them below their player card. These treasures are now safe for purchasing in the next phase.
   - If a player's hearts are all on the "injury" side, they fall, discard all treasures collected in that run, and remove their character from the level tile.

**Buy Phase**:
   - Starting with the first player and proceeding clockwise, players may purchase buildings and additional hearts:
     - **Buildings**: Discard the required number of unique treasure types (as indicated on the building card) to acquire a building, placing it next to their player card. Each building provides benefits, such as immediate coins or ongoing abilities.
     - **Hearts**: Discard the required number of matching treasure cards (refer to the heart cost card) to gain an additional heart token, increasing survivability in future runs.
   - Players may purchase multiple buildings and hearts but can buy only one of each building type per turn.

**Night Phase**:
   - Pass the first-player token to the next player clockwise.
   - Players may store one unused treasure card under each building they own; all other unused treasures are discarded.
   - Activate any building abilities marked with a moon symbol.
   - Reset all heart tokens to the "heart" side on player cards.
   - Shuffle all level cards back into the level deck, preparing for the next round.
QuickSetupGuide.EndOfGame: The game ends when all the dungeon cards have been used. The player with the most points wins.

QuickSetupGuide.Overview: A cooperative crime-solving game where players search for clues on a city map to solve different mysteries.
QuickSetupGuide.Setup:
**Prepare the Map**: Unfold the city map and place it on a large, well-lit surface accessible to all players. Ensure the entire map is visible, and consider playing on a table, floor, or even hanging the map on a wall.

**Organize Case Cards**: The game includes 16 distinct cases, each comprising a deck of case cards marked with a unique icon and card number. Sort these cards into their respective envelopes in numerical order.

**Magnifying Glass**: Affix the provided sticker to the magnifying glass and keep it handy for examining small details on the map.

**Player Arrangement**: Position all players so they have a clear view of the map and can move around it freely to observe from different angles.
QuickSetupGuide.PlayerSetup:
- **Lead Investigator**: Choose one player to act as the Lead Investigator. This person is responsible for reading the case cards aloud and guiding the team through the investigation.

- **Detective Team**: The remaining players form the detective team, collaborating to analyze the map and discuss findings based on the information provided by the Lead Investigator.
QuickSetupGuide.Gameplay:
**Initiate the Case**: Select a case envelope and remove the deck of case cards. The Lead Investigator reveals the start card, which provides an overview of the crime and depicts the main character. They read the back of this card aloud to the team.

**Solve Tasks**: The front of the next card presents the first task. The Lead Investigator reads this task aloud without revealing the back of the card. Players then search the map to find the scene that answers the task.

**Verify Solutions**: Once players believe they've found the correct scene, the Lead Investigator checks the back of the task card to confirm if the coordinates and illustration match the team's findings. If correct, the Lead Investigator reads the accompanying text aloud, and the team proceeds to the next task. If incorrect, the team must continue their search, with the Lead Investigator providing subtle hints if necessary.

**Continue Investigation**: Repeat the process for each subsequent task, with the Lead Investigator guiding the team through the narrative and challenges until all tasks in the case are resolved.
QuickSetupGuide.EndOfGame: Crime City: The game ends when all mysteries are solved or when players fail to solve them in time.

QuickSetupGuide.Overview: A legacy-style city-building game where players develop their cities over time, changing the rules and elements as they go.
QuickSetupGuide.Setup:
**Game Board and Components**:
   - Each player receives:
     - 1 personal game board with a unique animal symbol.
     - A set of 24 building tiles corresponding to their game board's symbol, comprising:
       - 8 yellow residential buildings
       - 8 red public buildings
       - 8 blue industrial buildings
     - 1 scoring token, placed on the number 10 of the scoring track.

**Construction Cards**:
   - Shuffle the 24 construction cards and place them face down in the center. These cards dictate the order in which buildings are placed during the game.

**Chapter Envelopes**:
   - The game includes 8 sealed envelopes, each containing new rules and components for three episodes. Open only the envelope corresponding to the current chapter being played.
QuickSetupGuide.PlayerSetup:
- **Initial Placement**:
  - Players write the name of their city in the designated space on their game board.
  - Place all 24 building tiles face up beside the game board for easy access.
  - Ensure the scoring token is on the number 10 of the scoring track.
QuickSetupGuide.Gameplay:
**Drawing Construction Cards**:
   - Flip the top construction card to reveal a building. All players simultaneously take the corresponding building tile and place it on their game board.

**Placement Rules**:
   - Buildings must be placed on light green spaces (plains); mountains (gray) and forests (dark green) are off-limits.
   - The first building must be placed adjacent to the river.
   - Subsequent buildings must be orthogonally adjacent to an existing building.
   - Buildings cannot straddle the river but can align along its edge.
   - Covering spaces with trees or rocks is optional but affects scoring:
     - Visible trees: +1 point each at game's end.
     - Visible rocks: -1 point each at game's end.
   - Once placed, buildings cannot be moved.

**Passing and Ending Participation**:
   - If unable or unwilling to place a building, a player may pass, losing 1 point.
   - Players can choose to end their participation after any card draw, retaining their current score but ceasing further building placements for that episode.

**Episode Conclusion**:
   - The episode ends when all players have ended their participation or all construction cards have been drawn.
QuickSetupGuide.EndOfGame: The game ends after a set number of rounds, and the player with the most points wins.

QuickSetupGuide.Overview: A deck-building game where players control druidic powers to purify the land, using transparent cards to create custom effects.
QuickSetupGuide.Setup:
**Setup the Common Area**:
   - **Advancement Decks**: Separate advancements into Level 1, Level 2, and Level 3 piles. Shuffle each and place them face down, then reveal the top four cards of each deck, laying them in a row to form the commons.
   - **Vale Decks**: Separate vale cards into Level 1 and Level 2 piles. Shuffle each and place them face down, then reveal the top four cards of each deck, placing them above the corresponding advancement rows.
   - **Mana Tokens**: Place the mana tokens within reach of all players.
   - **Victory Point (VP) Tokens**: Create a VP token pool based on the number of players:
     - 2 players: 23 VP tokens
     - 3 players: 28 VP tokens
     - 4 players: 33 VP tokens
   - **Starting Player**: Randomly determine the first player and give them the starting player marker.
QuickSetupGuide.PlayerSetup:
- **Personal Decks**: Each player receives a deck of 20 cards, consisting of:
  - 9 Cursed Lands (each with a decay symbol)
  - 3 Fertile Soils (providing 1 mana each)
  - 8 blank cards
- **Deck Preparation**: Shuffle your deck thoroughly and place it face down in front of you.
- **Mana Token**: Each player takes one mana token, which can be used to store mana between turns.
- **Field and On-Deck Area**: Designate space in front of you for your field (where played cards will go) and an on-deck area (for the top card of your deck).
QuickSetupGuide.Gameplay:
**Planting Phase**:
   - **Prepare the Field**: At the start of your turn, if you have fewer than three decay symbols showing between your field and on-deck card, continue revealing cards from your deck into your field until you have three decay symbols visible.
   - **Optional Push**: You may choose to "push" by revealing an additional card from your deck. If this card causes the total decay symbols to reach four, you "spoil" and your turn ends immediately. If not, you can continue to the Harvest Phase.

**Harvest Phase**:
   - **Collect Mana and Symbols**: Count the total mana and spirit symbols (life, death, wild) present in your field.
   - **Purchase Advancements**: Spend your collected mana to buy up to two advancements from the commons. Immediately sleeve each purchased advancement into a card in your field, adhering to sleeving rules (each card can have up to three advancements, one per section).
   - **Acquire Vale Cards**: Use collected spirit symbols to acquire vale cards from the available pool. These cards provide ongoing benefits or end-game VP and are placed beside your play area upon acquisition.

**Discard Phase**:
   - **Field to Discard Pile**: Move all cards from your field to your discard pile.
   - **Reset On-Deck Card**: Place the current on-deck card into your discard pile and reveal a new on-deck card from your deck.

**Prep Phase**:
   - **Prepare for Next Turn**: Continue revealing cards from your deck into your field until you have three decay symbols visible between your field and on-deck card. This setup ensures your next turn begins with the appropriate number of decay symbols showing.
QuickSetupGuide.EndOfGame: The game ends after a set number of rounds, and the player with the most points wins.

QuickSetupGuide.Overview: A cooperative deduction game where players work together to escape from a magical library while one player secretly tries to sabotage them.
QuickSetupGuide.Setup:
**Game Board Setup**:
   - Place the Library board at the center of the table.
   - Position the Progress marker on the first space of the Progress track.

**Role Assignment**:
   - Select one player as the Grimoire; they will provide clues and manage the game components.
   - The Grimoire takes the Grimoire book, magnetic desk board, two Butterfly tokens, the hourglass, and the deck of Door cards.
   - The remaining players are Wizards. Prepare role cards by including one Traitor card and Loyal Wizard cards to match the number of Wizards. Shuffle and deal one to each Wizard player secretly.

**Player Components**:
   - Each Wizard selects a Character card and the corresponding colored token.
   - Place all Wizard tokens in the center of the Library board.

**Cohesion Tokens**:
   - Determine the number of Cohesion tokens based on the desired difficulty:
     - Easy: 12 tokens
     - Medium: 10 tokens
     - Hard: 8 tokens
   - Place the tokens on the designated area of the Library board.

**Trap Tokens**:
   - Place all 14 Trap tokens into the bag and mix them.

**Grimoire Preparation**:
   - The Grimoire shuffles the Door deck and places eight cards into the Grimoire book, ensuring only they can see them.
QuickSetupGuide.PlayerSetup:
-**Grimoire**:
  - Reviews the eight Door cards in the Grimoire book.
  - Prepares to provide visual clues using the Butterfly tokens.

- **Wizards**:
  - Secretly view their role card to determine if they are a Loyal Wizard or the Traitor.
  - Familiarize themselves with their Character card and place their token on the Library board.
QuickSetupGuide.Gameplay:
**Trap Phase**:
   - The Grimoire draws one Trap token from the bag and reveals it, applying its effect for the current round.

**Clue Phase**:
   - The Grimoire draws the top Door card from the deck; this is the Exit card for the round.
   - The Grimoire then draws two additional Door cards and places them on the magnetic desk board.
   - Using the Butterfly tokens, the Grimoire highlights specific elements on these two cards to guide the Wizards toward the Exit card.

**Traitor's Selection**:
   - All Wizards close their eyes. The Grimoire asks the Traitor to open their eyes.
   - The Grimoire shows the Traitor the eight cards in the Grimoire book. The Traitor silently selects up to two cards they believe will mislead the Wizards.
   - The Grimoire adds these selected cards to the Exit card.

**Door Selection**:
   - The Grimoire adds additional random Door cards to the selected ones until there are six cards total.
   - These six cards are shuffled and placed face-up around the Library board.
   - The Wizards discuss and place their tokens in front of the Door card they believe is the Exit, within the time limit imposed by the hourglass.
   - The Grimoire reveals the correct Exit card:
     - If at least one Wizard chose correctly, advance the Progress marker by one space.
     - Wizards who chose incorrectly take a Cohesion token from the board.

**End of Round**:
   - Discard all Door cards used in the round.
   - Return all Trap tokens to the bag.
   - Reset Wizard tokens to the center of the board.
   - If the Progress marker reaches the final space and the Wizards successfully identify the Exit, they escape, and the game ends.
   - If all Cohesion tokens are removed, the Traitor wins, and the game ends.
QuickSetupGuide.EndOfGame: The game ends when the players uncover the traitor or escape the library successfully.

QuickSetupGuide.Overview: A dungeon crawler game where players explore dungeons, fight monsters, and level up to defeat the dungeon boss.
QuickSetupGuide.Setup:
**Select Heroes**: Each player chooses a hero card. For solo play, use the 1P side; for two players, use the 2P side.

**Choose Dungeon**: Select a dungeon card and place it with the first floor visible.

**Prepare Deck**: Shuffle all encounter cards to form the encounter deck. Place the stairs card at the bottom.

**Set Level Cards**: Stack level cards with Level 1 on top.

**Organize Tokens and Dice**: Place all dice and tokens within reach.
QuickSetupGuide.PlayerSetup:
- **Hero Setup**: Each player places their hero card in front of them, ensuring the appropriate side (1P or 2P) is facing up.

- **Starting Equipment**: Players begin with the attributes and skills shown on their hero cards.

- **Potion Tokens**: Place potion tokens on the Turn Reference card, accessible to all players.
QuickSetupGuide.Gameplay:
**Time Passes**: At the start of each turn, discard two cards from the encounter deck to represent the passage of time.

**Explore or Enter a Room**:
   - *Explore*: If fewer than four face-down doors are present, draw cards from the encounter deck to place face-down doors until there are four.
   - *Enter a Room*: Choose a face-down door to reveal an encounter. Decide to face the encounter or flee:
     - *Face Encounter*: Engage in combat or peril by rolling dice to match challenge boxes on the encounter card.
     - *Flee*: Close the door without consequences; the turn ends.

**Resolve Encounters**:
   - *Combat*:
     - Roll dice corresponding to your hero's attributes.
     - Use skills and potions to modify dice results.
     - Place dice on the encounter card to cover challenge boxes.
     - Suffer consequences for any uncovered boxes (damage or time loss).
   - *Peril*:
     - Choose one of two challenges.
     - Roll and assign dice as in combat.

**Claim Loot**: After a successful encounter, choose one:
   - *Item*: Slide the card under your hero card to gain attribute bonuses.
   - *Skill*: Place the card below your hero card to acquire a new skill.
   - *Potion*: Add a new potion type by placing the card under the Turn Reference card.
   - *Experience (XP)*: Slide the card under the current level card to gain XP.

**Level Up**: Accumulate XP to reach new levels, allowing more items and skills, and granting additional benefits.

**Descending**: After the encounter deck is exhausted, the stairs card appears. Choose to descend to the next dungeon floor, increasing difficulty and rewards.

**Boss Battle**: After three floors, face the dungeon boss. Defeat the boss by covering its challenge boxes over multiple rounds to win the game.
QuickSetupGuide.EndOfGame: The game ends when the dungeon is cleared or when the player loses all their health.

QuickSetupGuide.Overview: Social deduction game where players take on secret roles, trying to uncover the werewolves among them in a single night.
QuickSetupGuide.Setup:
1. Select the roles to be used and gather the corresponding role cards and tokens.
2. Shuffle the role cards and deal one to each player.
3. Place the remaining role cards in the center.
4. Use the app or a moderator to guide the game.
QuickSetupGuide.PlayerSetup:
- Select roles based on the number of players and shuffle them.
- Deal one role card to each player and three in the center.
- Give each player a role card face down.
- Place the role reminder tiles in the center.
- Distribute one token per player if using expansions.
QuickSetupGuide.Gameplay:
**1. All players receive a secret role.**  
**2. The night phase occurs: roles perform their actions in order.**  
**3. The day phase begins: players discuss and debate who is a Werewolf.**  
**4. After a time limit, players vote on whom to eliminate.**  
**5. The game ends immediately after the vote.**
QuickSetupGuide.EndOfGame:
- The game ends after a single night phase and voting round.  
- The team (Villagers or Werewolves) with the most favorable outcome wins.

QuickSetupGuide.Overview: A cooperative game where players work together to stop the spread of diseases and prevent global outbreaks.
QuickSetupGuide.Setup:
**Board and Components**: Place the game board depicting a world map with interconnected cities in the center. Position the infection rate marker on the "2" spot of the infection rate track and the outbreak marker on the "0" space of the outbreak track. Place one research station in Atlanta.

**Disease Cubes**: Separate the disease cubes by color (blue, yellow, black, and red) and place them in supply piles.

**Infection Deck**: Shuffle the infection cards and draw nine cards to seed the board:
   - First 3 cards: Place 3 cubes of the corresponding color on each city.
   - Next 3 cards: Place 2 cubes on each city.
   - Last 3 cards: Place 1 cube on each city.
   Place these cards face-up in the infection discard pile.

**Player Deck**: Remove the epidemic cards and shuffle the remaining player cards. Deal cards to each player based on the number of participants:
   - 2 players: 4 cards each
   - 3 players: 3 cards each
   - 4 players: 2 cards each
   Shuffle the epidemic cards back into the player deck according to the desired difficulty level:
   - Introductory: 4 epidemics
   - Standard: 5 epidemics
   - Heroic: 6 epidemics
   Divide the player deck into equal piles, shuffle an epidemic card into each pile, and stack them to form the player draw pile.

**Role Assignment**: Shuffle the role cards and deal one to each player. Each play
QuickSetupGuide.PlayerSetup:
- **Roles**: Each player assumes a unique role with special abilities, such as the Medic who can remove all cubes of a color in one action or the Scientist who needs only four cards to discover a cure.

- **Starting Position**: All player pawns begin in Atlanta, where the initial research station is located.

- **Hand Limit**: Players must not exceed a hand of seven cards. If they do, they must immediately discard cards or play event cards to comply with the limit.
QuickSetupGuide.Gameplay:
**Player Actions**: On a turn, a player can perform up to four actions, choosing from:
   - **Move**: Travel between cities by various methods.
   - **Treat Disease**: Remove a disease cube from the current city.
   - **Share Knowledge**: Exchange city cards with another player in the same city.
   - **Build Research Station**: Construct a station in the current city by discarding the matching city card.
   - **Discover a Cure**: At a research station, discard five city cards of the same color to cure that disease.

**Draw Player Cards**: After actions, draw two player cards. If an epidemic card is drawn:
   - Increase the infection rate.
   - Draw the bottom infection card and place three cubes on that city.
   - Shuffle the infection discard pile and place it on top of the infection deck.

**Infect Cities**: Flip over infection cards equal to the current infection rate and add one cube of the corresponding color to each city drawn. If a city already has three cubes of that color, an outbreak occurs, spreading the disease to connected cities and advancing the outbreak marker.
QuickSetupGuide.EndOfGame: The game ends if players successfully contain the diseases, or if the diseases spread beyond control.

QuickSetupGuide.Overview: A quick and easy card game where players try to create the best salad by collecting different vegetables and bonus points.
QuickSetupGuide.Setup:
**Deck Preparation**:
   - Shuffle all 108 cards thoroughly.

**Creating Draw Piles**:
   - Divide the shuffled deck into three approximately equal draw piles.
   - Place each pile face-up (scoring side visible) in the center of the table.

**Forming the Market**:
   - Draw two cards from each draw pile and place them vegetable-side up below their respective piles, creating a market of six vegetable cards.

**Adjusting for Player Count**:
   - For 2-3 players: Remove 2 types of vegetables from the game (36 cards).
   - For 4-5 players: Use all 108 cards.
   - For 6 players: Use all 108 cards and consider playing in teams or with adjusted rules for balance.
QuickSetupGuide.PlayerSetup:
- **Starting Player**: Determine a starting player by any random method.

- **Player Area**: Each player should have space in front of them to place their drafted cards, organizing them into two sections:
  - **Vegetable Cards**: Cards taken for their vegetable side.
  - **Scoring Cards**: Cards taken for their scoring condition side.
QuickSetupGuide.Gameplay:
**Player Turn**:
   - On your turn, choose one of the following actions:
     - **Take Two Vegetable Cards**: Select any two vegetable cards from the market.
     - **Take One Scoring Card**: Select one face-up scoring card from any of the draw piles.

**Refilling the Market**:
   - After taking cards, immediately refill the market by drawing cards from the corresponding draw pile(s) to replace the empty spots, ensuring there are always six vegetable cards available.

**Optional Card Flip**:
   - At any point during your turn, you may flip one of your previously acquired scoring cards to its vegetable side. This can be done once per turn and is irreversible.

**End of Turn**:
   - Play proceeds clockwise to the next player.

**Game End**:
   - The game continues until all cards have been drafted from the draw piles and the market.
QuickSetupGuide.EndOfGame: The game ends when all cards are drawn, and the player with the most points wins.

QuickSetupGuide.Overview: A push-your-luck card game where players explore the Caribbean, recruit crew, and loot ships for profit.
QuickSetupGuide.Setup:
**Preparation**:
   - If playing with fewer than 5 players, remove the special Expedition card (identifiable by the absence of a coin on its back) and return it to the box. In a 5-player game, place this card in the center of the table.
   - Shuffle the remaining cards to form a face-down draw pile. Leave space for a discard pile.

**Starting Coins**:
   - Each player receives 3 coins. To represent this, deal 3 cards face-down from the draw pile to each player; the back of each card depicts a coin. Players should not look at the front of these cards.

**Player Order**:
   - The player who most recently visited a harbor becomes the starting player.
QuickSetupGuide.PlayerSetup:
- **Personal Display**: Arrange your 3 coin cards face-down in front of you, ensuring the coin side is visible.
- **Understanding Cards**: Familiarize yourself with the different card types:
  - **Ships**: Offer coins when traded.
  - **Persons**: Provide abilities and influence points when hired.
  - **Expeditions**: Require specific symbols from hired persons to complete for rewards.
  - **Tax Increases**: Trigger events affecting players' coins and influence.
QuickSetupGuide.Gameplay:
**Phase 1: Discover**:
   - As the active player, draw cards one by one from the draw pile, placing them into the harbor display (the central play area).
   - After each draw, decide whether to continue drawing or stop.
   - Be cautious: if you draw a ship of the same color as one already in the harbor and cannot repel it, your turn ends immediately, and all cards in the harbor display are discarded.

**Phase 2: Trade & Hire** (if the turn wasn't forfeited):
   - **Active Player**:
     - Depending on the number of differently colored ships in the harbor display:
       - 0-3 different colors: Take 1 card.
       - 4 different colors: Take 2 cards.
       - 5 different colors: Take 3 cards.
     - Choose cards one at a time, either:
       - **Trade**: Discard a ship card to gain coins equal to its value.
       - **Hire**: Pay coins equal to a person's cost to add them to your personal display, gaining their abilities and influence points.
   - **Other Players**:
     - In clockwise order, each may take 1 card from the harbor display by paying the active player 1 coin as compensation.
     - After all interested players have taken a card, discard any remaining cards in the harbor display.

**Additional Rules**:
- **Repelling Ships**: If you have hired sailors or pirates providing enough swords, you can repel a newly drawn ship, discarding it immediately instead of adding it to the harbor display.
- **Tax Increase Cards**: When drawn, all players with 12 or more coins lose half their coins (rounded down). Additionally, a bonus coin is awarded to the player with the most swords or the least influence points, as indicated on the card.
- **Expeditions**: Active players can fulfill expeditions by discarding the required persons from their display, gaining the expedition card and its rewards.
QuickSetupGuide.EndOfGame: The game ends when a player reaches 12 points, and the player with the most points wins.

QuickSetupGuide.Overview: A deck-building game that combines match-3 style puzzles with strategic gameplay.
QuickSetupGuide.Setup:
**Choose a Character**: Each player selects a character and takes the corresponding 3 character-specific chips.
**Starting Deck**: Each player starts with 6 "Gem" chips (2x 1-gem and 4x 2-gem), 1 "Crash Gem", 1 "Combine", and 1 "Double Crash" chip.
**Setup the Bank**: Shuffle and place a selection of 10 different chips face-up in the center, forming the "Bank." These are the available chips players can buy during the game.
**Starting Gem Pile**: Each player places a single 1-gem chip in their gem pile.
**Draw Pile and Hand**: Players shuffle their starting chips to form a draw pile and draw 5 chips.
**Determine First Player**: Randomly select a starting player.
QuickSetupGuide.PlayerSetup:
- Each player starts with a personal bag containing their deck of chips.
- Players draw 5 chips at the beginning of each turn.
- Players start with one 1-gem in their gem pile.
- The character?s unique chips are placed in their deck from the start.
QuickSetupGuide.Gameplay:
**Ante**: At the start of each turn, the player antes one gem into their gem pile.
**Action Phase**: Play one action chip from your hand (if possible). Some chips allow additional actions.
**Buy Phase**: Spend gems to buy new chips from the Bank and add them to your discard pile.
**Cleanup Phase**: Discard unplayed chips, then draw back up to 5 chips.
